titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the New York Bureau of Legal Advice (New York Bureau of Legal First Aid) Records TAM 044 (R-7006)

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from NYBLA Guide.wpd

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2010-01-12T12:42-0500

did.unittitle: New York Bureau of Legal Advice Records
did.abstract: The New York Bureau of Legal First Aid was organized in 1917 with a grant from the Women's Peace Party. Lead by attorney Charles Recht and feminist Frances M. Witherspoon, it was the first organization to furnish free legal advice and counsel to anyone who came into conflict with the new laws related to America's entry into World War I, including draft resisters, conscientious objectors, and deserters. By 1918 it was aiding at least 5,000 clients and changed its name to the New York Bureau of Legal Advice (NYBLA). Though raided by the Bureau of Investigation in 1918, the NYBLA continued with its anti-war campaigns until shortly after the Armistice was signed. The records contain correspondence, office files, case histories, clippings, and press releases relating to selective service exemption, draft evasion, conscientious objector status, military discharge, desertion, amnesty, civil liberties and deportation. NOTE: this collection has been microfilmed, and researchers must use microfilm copy (R-7006).

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The 1917-1919 records of the New York Bureau of Legal Advice had been stored in the Tamiment Library Collection among old file boxes and cartons relating to World War I. In 1961 Professor Martin David Dubin of Roosevelt University began researching, processing and ordering the papers of the Bureau. He returned the collection to Tamiment Library in 13 document boxes (5.5 linear feet) in 1970. The Swarthmore College Peace Collection also holds a large fragment of the organization's office files, "which fit into the Tamiment portions like parts of a jigsaw puzzle," according to Professor Dubin. Also in the Swarthmore College Peace Collection are the personal papers of two principles of the organization, Frances M. Witherspoon, Secretary of the Bureau and Tracy Dickinson Mygatt, a member of the Executive Committee and Miss Witherspoon's companion.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research without restrictions. Researchers must use microfilm (Reels 7006/1-10).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The New York Bureau of Legal First Aid was organized on May 11, 1917 with a one hundred dollar grant from the Women's Peace Party. Individuals contributed to the treasury and in August the People's Council, the Socialist Party, the Civil Liberties Bureau and the Workmen's Council all became sponsoring affiliates. A few months later the People's Council and the Civil Liberties Bureau withdrew their support, but a strong Executive Committee continued the organizing work. In May, 1918 the organization changed its name to the New York Bureau of Legal Advice (NYBLA). During that year, the Bureau estimated that it had aided at least 5,000 clients. In September 1918, a raid by the Bureau of Investigation disrupted organizational functioning temporarily; NYBLA continued with its anti-war campaigns and only ended its work in the autumn of 1919, shortly before the Armistice.

NYBLA was the first organization to furnish free legal advice and counsel to anyone who came into conflict with the new laws related to America's entry into World War I, including draft resisters, conscientious objectors, and deserters. The Bureau sought to gather information and investigate and publicize war-related instances of infringements of First Amendment rights. The Bureau campaigned for amnesty for conscientious objectors and also monitored their treatment in military prisons; lobbying by NYBLA was instrumental in forcing Secretary of War Newton B. Baker to order an end to the practice of holding conscientious objectors in manacles. The Bureau cooperated actively with the Industrial Workers of the World and other radical groups in defense of free speech and in opposition to the deportation of immigrant radicals.

Charles Recht, a Czech-born attorney, was the General Counsel of the Bureau. As Secretary of the Bureau Frances M. Witherspoon, an ardent feminist and socialist peace activist carried on the daily work of the Bureau, including fundraising, working with attorneys and volunteers, organizing lobbying campaigns, maintaining correspondence, and interviewing clients. She worked with the leading socialists, anti-war activists and civil libertarians of the time, including Roger N. Baldwin, Ella Reeve ("Mother") Bloor, M. Eleanor Fitzgerald, Albert De Silver, Jacob Hillquit, and Scott Nearing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: About half the records of the New York Bureau of Legal Advice consist of case histories pertaining to selective service exemption, draft evasion, conscientious objector status, military imprisonment, military discharge, desertion, amnesty, civil liberties and deportations. One third of the collection consists of office files, administrative reports and correspondence, including extensive fundraising correspondence. The remainder of the collection is made up of press releases and newspaper clippings.

The case histories, chiefly relating to draft exemption, provide significant and frequently poignant information on the daily lives and problems of the working class immigrants who were the principal clients of the Bureau's pioneering efforts to deliver free legal services and to protect poor people's civil rights. The correspondence and office files reflect civil liberties activity and the Bureau's role as a connecting link between "those on the firing line in anti-war agitation" and America's large and politically diverse peace and socialist movements.

The correspondents to the NYBLA are numerous and varied; many well known progressives of the period made a contribution to the Bureau's work. Among them are Mary Beard, Sarah N. Cleghorn, Elizabeth Gurley and Bina Flynn, Agnes Smedley, Louis Untermeyer, Thorsten Veblen, H. L. Mencken, Sinclair Lewis, Judah L. Magnes, and Stephen Wise.

The materials of the NYBLA were in precarious condition by summer of 1990 and were microfilmed at Tamiment Library through the Research Libraries Group Archives Preservation Microfilming Project. The collection maintains Professor Dubin's arrangement, which is ordered in six series:

This series consists of administrative materials such as by-laws, executives' reports, minutes, funding circulars, policy statements, publicity brochures, membership and mailing lists, legal correspondence, government forms, conference materials, drafts and manuscripts, logs of cases, bills, and other office materials.

This series consists of correspondence with individuals and organizations. Along with individual correspondents' files, there are files of Miscellaneous writers after each alphabetical category. A substantial number of the letters are carbons of Miss Witherspoon's fund raising messages. Her individual appeals to friends of the bureau and assiduous hunt for donations and pledges led her to correspond with such noteworthy supporters as H. L. Mencken, Sinclair Lewis, Louis Untermeyer, Thorsten Veblen, and Upton Sinclair. The correspondence files also show that a strong network of progressive organizations bolstered the NYBLA.
III: Case Files--Aliens, Deportations, Special Individuals

This series contains correspondence, affidavits, legal notices, clippings and legal transcripts relating to deportations and other actions threatened by the government against immigrants and opponents of the war effort. Notable among these papers are documents of the Chinese United Association, a Chinatown labor organization, and case files on Gertrude Pignol, a New York City high school teacher dismissed from her position because of her opposition to the war, and on the Italian labor activist Arturo Giovanetti.

The Conscientious Objectors files include correspondence with the CO's and with their families as well as affidavits, court martial records, and correspondence with military officials. Subjects of correspondence include lobbying campaigns, prison brutality, strikes and hunger strikes by prisoners, and the progress of cases. There are also files on the military camps where the COs were incarcerated.
V: Case Files--Draft Boards, Aliens Dependents

Most of the individual cases in these files concern the working class clients of the NYBLA. Correspondence with clients and families, affidavits, and correspondence with military officials are included in this series. Their requests for excuse from military service usually concerned their immigrant status or their family responsibilities.

p.emph: VI: Press Releases and Newspaper Clippings

scopecontent.p: Most of the clippings collected here come from articles in The Call or The New York Times. Topics range from free speech issues to amnesty of conscientious objectors to deportation legislation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Office Files; II. Correspondence; III. Case Files--Aliens, Deportations, Special Individuals; IV. Case Files-Conscientious Objectors; V. Case Files-Draft Boards, Aliens, Dependents; VI. Press Releases and Newspaper Clippings.
Folders are generally arranged alphabetically by subject/author heading then chronologically within each subject/author heading.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

archref.extref: American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born Records.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: 18 photographic images were separated and added to the Library's non-print collection as Tamiment NP 26.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: peter.filardo@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
